prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
We use a standard Band 7 single continuum spectral setup, with a central freqency of 343.5 GHz and a 7.5 GHz bandwidth. NGC 3626 is not located within 10 degrees of any other targets and will be observed separately.
We have no mid-infrared, far-infrared, or submillimetre images with sufficient resolution to allow us to produce any models that approximate the dust discs. However, the total 343.5 GHz flux density (estimated by fitting modified blackbodies to the 160-500 micron data from Ciesla et al. (2012) and Cortese et al. (2013)) are similar to the flux densities for NGC 4370, 4429, 4435, 4459, and 4469, and we anticipate that the spatial extent of the dust will be similar to the spatial extent of the dust in these other galaxies, so we assume that we will need to reach the same sensitivity limit.
The goal is to achieve rms noise levels of 0.05 mJy/beam when integrating over the 7.5 GHz band. This will allow us to detect the discs at the 3 sigma level out to radii of ~3.75 arcsec, which should encompass at least half of the total flux densities and which should be sufficient for measuring the radial profiles of the dust discs. The estimated total on-source observing time per target is 18.4 min, and the total estimated observing time for this science goal is 58.7 min.
We anticipate that most of the emission will originate from structures that are ~7.5 arcsec or smaller. Moreover, when we ran simulations of the observations of the model images for similar galaxies (NGC 4370, 4429, 4435, 4459, and 4469) using the Observation Support Tool, we were able to detect the largest scale structures in the models. Hence, the target can be observed in a single pointing, and no ACA observations are needed.

We use a standard Band 7 single continuum spectral setup, with a central freqency of 343.5 GHz and a 7.5 GHz bandwidth. NGC 4370, 4429, 4435, 4459, and 4469 are all to be observed using single pointings and all lie within 10 degrees of each other, so they have all been grouped together in a single science goal for efficiency.
To estimate the surface brightnesses, we applied the image-fitting analysis from Young et al. (2009) to the 24 micron images from Bendo et al. (2012b). We then rescaled the model dust disc components using flux density values estimated by fitting modified blackbodies to the 160-500 micron data from Ciesla et al. (2012) and Cortese et al. (2013). For NGC 4370, 4429, 4435, 4459, and 4469, the goal is to achieve rms noise levels of 0.05 mJy/beam when integrating over the 7.5 GHz band. This will allow us to detect the discs at the 3 sigma level out to radii of ~3.75 arcsec, which should encompass at least half of the total flux densities and which should be sufficient for measuring the radial profiles of the dust discs. The estimated total on-source observing time per target is 18.4 min, and the total estimated observing time for this science goal is 3.2 h.
We anticipate that most of the emission will originate from structures that are ~7.5 arcsec or smaller. Moreover, when we ran simulations of the observations of the model images using the Observation Support Tool, we were able to detect the largest scale structures in the models. Hence, the target can be observed in a single pointing, and no ACA observations are needed.

We use a standard Band 7 single continuum spectral setup, with a central freqency of 343.5 GHz and a 7.5 GHz bandwidth. NGC 4526 and 4710 are to be observed using multiple pointings and with the ACA, and they lie within 10 degrees of each other, so they have all been grouped together in a single science goal for efficiency.
Each source will be observed using two pointings spaced by 12 arcsec to cover the extended emission from the dust structures. We are expecting the source structure to be <~11.5 arcsec, which is larger than what can be measured by the 12 m antennas but smaller than what can be measured with the ACA, so we are also requesting ACA observations of these targets.
To estimate the surface brightnesses, we applied the image-fitting analysis from Young et al. (2009) to the 24 micron image of NGC 4526 from Bendo et al. (2012b) and the 12 micron image of NGC 4710 from Bendo et al. (2002) (which was the best alternative image available given that no Spitzer 24 micron image exist for the target, even though stellar emission still dominates the 12 micron band). We then rescaled the model dust disc components using flux density values estimated by fitting modified blackbodies to the 160-500 micron data from Ciesla et al. (2012) and Cortese et al. (2013). For NGC 4526 and 4710, the goal is to achieve rms noise levels of 0.1 mJy/beam when integrating over the 7.5 GHz band. This will allow us to detect the discs at the 3 sigma level to a 5.75 arcsec radius, which should encompass at least half of the total flux densities and which should be sufficient for measuring the radial profiles of the dust discs. To achieve these sensitivities, the OT currently provides a total observing time estimate of 2.67 h, which can be divided into 0.89 h with the 12 m array and 1.78 h for the ACA.
Note that the pointings for NGC 4710 are offset 2 arcsec in RA and 1 arcsec in Dec from the positions given by NED. Most other optical, near-infrared, and mid-infrared images that we have show that the centre of the galaxy is slightly offset from the NED coordinates by approximately this amount.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: A subset of early-type galaxies contain dust that produce infrared and submillimetre emission, but until the advent of ALMA, it has not been possible to actually map the dust structures within these galaxies. We propose to perform band 7 (343.5 GHz) observations of compact dust structures within 8 early-type galaxies. The goals are to map the dust structures in an effect to search for asymmetries (which would indicate that the dust was recently accreted), to identify dust heating sources using an empirical approach, to apply radiative transfer models to further study the dust heating and measure the clumpiness of the dust clouds, and to serendipitously detect CO J=(3-2) emission.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:previousProposals:
2011.0.00238.S (Mapping compact cold dust emission within nearby early-type galaxies NGC 4459 and NGC 4526; PI: George Bendo): No time awarded.
2012.1.00780.S (Mapping dust discs in early-type Virgo Cluster galaxies; PI: George Bendo): No time awarded.
